title: AAQ: Are Devotees Made by Destiny or Choice? The Real Answer!" | His Grace Madhu Pandit Dasa
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: Now you have free will. How to respond to your subtle body, your gross body and your kala.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the question of destiny versus choice, explaining that while external factors are governed by karma, the soul has free will to respond to them.

segments.key_quote: Even a dog has a free will.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of interacting with a dog to illustrate that even animals have free will to react to their environment, suggesting life is a combination of free will and destiny.

segments.key_quote: My destiny is nothing but my past free will.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that destiny is a result of past free will, not arbitrary divine intervention, and uses the analogy of a cow tied to a tree to illustrate the limits and freedom within destiny.

segments.key_quote: So potentially speaking, it is my free will alone that exists. My destiny is nothing but my past free will.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of wanting to fly like a bird to show limitations, and a boil to illustrate how free will can influence the manifestation of karma.

segments.key_quote: Sukha Dukha, you have created according to your karma, you have to face it.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that while the form of suffering may be altered, the underlying karma must be experienced, and reiterates that destiny doesn't dictate every action, using the dog example again.

segments.key_quote: The soul is there, acting. He is not a robotic dog.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that even the dog's actions are not purely mechanical, but influenced by the soul's willing, distinguishing it from a robotic response.

segments.key_quote: Free will is an illusion in this world... A decision maker is a soul.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that 'free will' is actually 'willing' influenced by the modes of nature, and that true free will exists in the spiritual world through Krishna consciousness.

segments.key_quote: The rope has given you that freedom. 100 feet circle, you can go what you want.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the rope analogy again to illustrate the limited freedom within material existence, emphasizing that desires are not always attainable and that association influences our 'willing'.

segments.key_quote: Willing, only the Jeeva Shakti can will.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by stating that only the Jeeva Shakti can will, and then the transcript becomes unclear.
